note: Coin of Tiberius (14-37 A.D.). youthful head of deified Julius Caesar.
title: B.c.) of Augustus with 9

note: The short hair of these emperors reflects their military lives, their short reigns, the troubled times. 1% times actual size.
title: Coins from the time of crisis. Aurelian (270-275 A.D.), Florianus (276 A.D.) and Probus (276-282 A.D.). From a group found embedded in the fortification wall built in Athens around 280 A.D. to prevent a repetition of the barbarian raid of 267

container-title: 4th century B.C. Below: signature of Praxiteles beneath the statue of Kleiokrateia
title: Base for statues of Kleiokrateia and her husband Spoudias

container-title: Miniature portrait of a lady of the time of Trajan (98-117A.D.). The elaborate coiffure seems to be a wig, with the natural hair showing in front. The features have a negroid cast. s 1268.H. 4%”
title: 1 . Portrait of a young woman. Early 1st century A.D. Her coiffure is like those of the empress Livia and of Antonia the Younger, but the features are more gentle. s 1631
Statue of a man wearing the himation (pallium). and century A.D. s 1354
Portrait of a priest of Isis. 1st century B.C. Influenced by Egyptian works, this powerful portrait suggests one source for the famed realism of Roman Republican portraiture

note: Head of a youth. 3rd century B.C. S 1208.H. 6%" (0.155 m.).
title: Base for a statue of Aurelius Appianus, son of the Kosmetes Aurelius Chrestus. First half of the 3rd century A.D. W e know from another inscription that this boy was killed by accident in a religious festivalbefore he could complete the ephebic training
Bust of a youth. 1st century A.D. s 1319

Heads of young boys. 3rd century A.D. The wreaths, probably of myrtle, suggest that they are initiates to the Eleusinian Mysteries. The long lock on the back of the head of 40 may have been grown for dedication to a divinity

Late 3rd or early 4th century A.D. Since the ephebic training in Athens seems to have ended shortly after 267 A.D., this youth with his Late Antique look may be a Roman prince rather than an Athenian ephebe. s 1406

note: Harrison, T h e Athenian Agora, I , Portrait Sculpture, Princeton, 1953.
title: Scratched on the south wall of the Stoa of Attalos. Before 280 A.D. For further information on most of the portraits in this booklet reference may be made to Evelyn B

They are also available in the Agora Museum
